stream_context.summary: Kaze programmed AI and behavior for two new enemies (Thimble Guy and Bert the Bashful) for a craft-themed level. This involved significant debugging of a complex rendering bug. He also conducted a detailed review of a major visual and performance overhaul for Course 1, which was submitted by the artist Biobak, and solicited feedback on a new music track from the composer Badub.

development_findings.summary: The team decided that Thimble Guys, being made of hard metal, will be defeated by knocking them off ledges like the Bullies in the original game, rather than by being stomped.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking they should work more like bully fights where you kick them off the thing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze solved a critical rendering bug with the Thimble Guy's head shine by inspecting the compiled assembly, discovering the compiler had silently generated faulty code due to a shadowed variable.
development_findings.quote: And this is why you don't trust your fucking compiler. You look at the assembly and then you find it out. Fuck you, GCC.

development_findings.summary: After importing Biobak's visually upgraded Course 1, Kaze tested it on N64 hardware and was relieved to find that performance was identical to the old version, with room for more optimization.
development_findings.quote: Wait, anti-aliasing indeed never turns stuff on again. This might not actually be worse. Okay, nevermind, it's the same performance. Cool, cool, cool.

development_findings.summary: A new enemy, Bert the Bashful, is being added. It is designed to look like a painted egg and will act as a bouncy obstacle, knocking Mario back without dealing damage, which is dangerous near pits.
The project is nearing the completion of its main courses, with a total scope of 15 main courses and around 15 additional levels.
development_findings.quote: The game will have about 30 levels in total, but 15 main courses and we're on the 14th.

development_findings.summary: The game will feature two types of collectibles: around 135 standard stars and 45 special 'Yoshi Stars' earned by completing challenges with unique restrictions.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna have, I think, around 135 main stars. And then we're gonna have 45 Yoshi stars. These Yoshi stars are missions that Yoshi's give you that have like special restrictions.

development_findings.summary: Kaze emphasizes the importance of a consistent artistic vision to elevate the project beyond a simple 'hack' into a cohesive, standalone game experience.
development_findings.quote: If you just add random stuff like spiral levels in there, you're kind of branding it as a hack and not like, you know, a proper game. Not a consistent vision.

development_findings.summary: After discovering the shadowed variable bug, Kaze enabled the -Wshadow compiler flag to receive warnings for such issues in the future.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a grand vision for the game's overworld to be the complete, explorable Yoshi's Island, fostering a sense of total immersion and discovery.
context_findings.quote: I was thinking for the overworld. It is super important that the overworld is the entirety of Yoshi's Island. It is important that you get like a 360Â° round view... so it feels like you can actually explore the entire island.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of the potential legal issues with the project, especially after Nintendo took down his previous game, and plans to seek legal advice before release.
context_findings.quote: I will probably talk to a lawyer Before I release R.T.Y.I.

context_findings.summary: Kaze sarcastically jokes about programming and 'woke' culture, linking the use of premade game engines to an inability to program and expressing a preference for creating his own engine.
context_findings.quote: The thing about woke people is they can't program, which is why they have to use premade engines like Unreal Engine or Unity or Godot, right? So if you use your own engine, it's not woke anymore. I learned this yesterday on Twitter.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains his dislike for the song 'Wonderwall' stems from associating it with people using it as a simple 'party trick' to impress others, separating the act of playing an instrument from being a true composer.
context_findings.quote: I've had that experience. I've seen that before. And the amount of disgust I feel from this whole situation is so high that by proxy I hate Wonderwall.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows excitement and a desire for validation from his community when sharing new creative ideas, particularly his vision for the game's overworld.
context_findings.quote: I had a revelation today... And I think you're gonna like this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze speculates that if he had chosen to mod Sonic Adventure instead of Mario 64, he would have become a millionaire, reflecting on his chosen creative path.
context_findings.quote: My whole life would be so different. I would be a millionaire.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's day job in the games industry hired him specifically because of his ROM hacking hobby.
Kaze mentions he is glad to no longer live in Germany due to its bureaucracy and now resides in Canada.

biobak.summary: Biobak delivered a massive visual and performance overhaul for Course 1, significantly reducing polygon and material counts while improving aesthetics with new models, textures, and layouts.
biobak.quote: Quick facts, 220 fewer tries, 7 fewer materials, that is insane.

biobak.summary: Kaze relies on Biobak to provide compelling screenshots of new level work to share with Patreon supporters and keep them engaged with the project's progress.
biobak.quote: I'll be fine, it's just a short preview for Patreons. I just don't want the people on Patreon to, like, not know that I've been working on...

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions a workflow dependency where he sometimes needs to correct texture formats in Biobak's work, as Biobak lacks the setup to test them in-game himself.
biobak.quote: I have to fix formats from Biobak's file. Because he doesn't always know what the correct formats are... he can't check it.

badub.summary: Badub composed a new song for Course 14, which Kaze critiqued on stream for not fitting the level's adventurous tone, though he acknowledged its beauty.
badub.quote: It doesn't fit the vibe. Feels more like a beach at sunset, not like a complete adventure, you know? And I'm also kinda missing the melody that you can hum along to.

zeina.summary: Zeina was mentioned only in a personal context, as Kaze noted they have recently started playing Minecraft together. Her professional contributions as an animator were not discussed.

key_stories.title: The Invincible Thimble Guy
key_stories.summary: The team faced a design problem with their new metal 'Thimble Guy' enemy, as stomping it didn't make sense. They decided to model its defeat condition after the classic 'Bully' enemies, requiring the player to knock them off platforms, creating a more engaging and logical fight.
key_stories.challenge: The newly designed 'Thimble Guy' enemy, being made of metal, couldn't be defeated by Mario's traditional stomp attack. Kaze needed a logical and fun alternative.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially considered making the enemies invincible before brainstorming ideas with his stream chat. The community-supported idea of treating them like Bullies was chosen, and Kaze programmed the knockback physics and AI to support this new behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a mechanic where players must kick the Thimble Guys off ledges, similar to the 'Bully' enemies from the original SM64. This solution was thematically appropriate and created a fun, physics-based combat encounter.
key_stories.key_quote: I was thinking they should work more like bully fights where you kick them off the thing.

key_stories.title: The Compiler's Betrayal
key_stories.summary: A frustrating, elusive rendering bug on an enemy's head took Kaze on a deep dive into the N64's rendering pipeline and even the compiled machine code. The culprit was not a logic error, but a subtle coding mistake that tricked the compiler into generating broken code, a problem he ultimately solved by distrusting his tools and inspecting their output directly.
key_stories.challenge: A dynamic shine effect on the Thimble Guy's head, meant to react to camera movement, was completely broken. The texture refused to move, and the bug behaved inconsistently across different emulators, making it a nightmare to diagnose.
key_stories.process: After failing to fix the issue with C code adjustments, Kaze resorted to debugging the raw assembly output. He noticed bizarre and incorrect instructions, which led him to suspect a compiler-level issue. By tracing the logic back, he identified the shadowed variable as the culprit.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze discovered that the C compiler (GCC) had silently generated faulty code because he had accidentally 'shadowed' a variable by declaring a new one with the same name inside an if-statement. After renaming the variable, the effect worked perfectly. He then enabled a compiler warning to prevent this specific issue in the future.
key_stories.key_quote: And this is why you don't trust your fucking compiler. You look at the assembly and then you find it out. Fuck you, GCC. Why didn't you warn me?

key_stories.title: The Course 1 Glow-Up
key_stories.summary: Artist Biobak delivered a huge rework of the game's first level, packed with visual upgrades. Kaze, though impressed, was concerned about performance, but an on-hardware test revealed the new level ran perfectly, proving that the team could push the game's visuals without sacrificing framerate.
key_stories.challenge: Course 1, as the game's opening level, needed a significant visual and performance upgrade to meet the project's quality standards without slowing down the N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Biobak, the project's artist, independently performed a massive overhaul of Course 1's geometry, textures, and layout. He then sent the updated files and a detailed changelog to Kaze, who reviewed the changes live on stream and then ran performance tests on a real N64 console.
key_stories.outcome: The rework was a resounding success. Kaze's hardware test confirmed that the visually superior level performed just as well as the original, with potential for even more optimization. This validated Biobak's artistic and technical efforts.
key_stories.key_quote: 220 fewer tries, 7 fewer materials, that is insane.

open_questions.context: Kaze played a new music track by Badub for Course 14. While praising its quality, Kaze felt it didn't fit the level's 'adventure' vibe and gave specific feedback on stream about what was missing.
questions: How do you and Badub typically collaborate on music? What is your shared process?
How do you approach giving constructive criticism on something as subjective as music to a key collaborator?
Badub, how do you take creative feedback like Kaze's and use it to iterate on a composition?

open_questions.context: Kaze enthusiastically shared a 'revelation' for the game's overworld: it should be the entire, seamless, 360-degree explorable Yoshi's Island, with progression tied to venturing deeper into it.
questions: What are the biggest technical and design hurdles in creating such a large, seamless overworld on the N64?
What games or experiences inspired this 'whole island' concept?
How do you plan to guide the player and structure progression in such an open space?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Nintendo had previously taken down one of his projects and that he plans to consult a lawyer before releasing this game. He also floated the idea of selling a physical OST cartridge.
questions: Can you describe your experience when Nintendo took down 'The Missing Link' and how it shaped your strategy for this project?
What are your specific legal concerns, and what do you hope to clarify by speaking with a lawyer?
How do you reconcile the project's fan-game nature with potentially commercial activities like selling merchandise?

open_questions.context: Zeina is Kaze's spouse and the project's animator, but her work was not discussed. Kaze spoke about his day job, which he got because of his modding hobby, and balancing his schedule.
questions: How do you and Zeina navigate the boundary between your personal relationship and your creative collaboration on this project?
Can you highlight some of Zeina's key contributions to the game's animation?
How do you balance the demands of a full-time job, this massive passion project, and your personal life?

open_questions.context: Kaze detailed a system of 'Yoshi Stars,' special objectives with unique gameplay restrictions (e.g., A-press limits), comparing them favorably to Mario Galaxy's Green Stars.
questions: What was the core design goal for the 'Yoshi Stars' system?
What makes this system 'less sucky' than the Green Stars in Super Mario Galaxy?
Can you provide examples of other types of restrictions players will face in these challenges?
